awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Bio-optical Sensor for the Direct Detection of Sinking Marine Particles
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

The broader impact of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is a stronger understanding of how living things absorb carbon in the ocean. It is important to have an accurate measure of the natural carbon uptake by the ocean because this affects ocean and fishery health, as well as future efforts to intentionally sequester carbon in the ocean to mitigate climate change. This goal will be achieved by developing a low-cost sensor that can be widely deployed on ocean robots, which are already being used to measure processes like ocean heat uptake. The sensor will use light to detect sinking debris in the ocean.  This debris is a major way that carbon is naturally sequestered in the ocean. Distributed, robotic platforms in the ocean allow observations to be made in locations and seasons that are not accessible with research ships. Such platforms are generally lower cost than sensors associated with research ships. Development and sale of sensors for robotic platforms are areas of growth because of the increasing reliance on these platforms for scientific observations. This project may also enhance academic and industry partnerships and help to train upcoming scientists and engineers in instrument development.

There is a significant desire to expand measurements of ocean biological carbon pump processes to better understand climate change, in particular the flux of carbon by particles settling out of the surface ocean. This project will create a sensor that is designed to be carried aboard globally distributed, autonomous profiling floats.  The sensors/floats may help distinguish among the different modes of biological carbon uptake in the ocean. The sensor will be designed from the ground up to meet the challenges of sampling floats, which have stringent power consumption, cost, and data quality-control requirements. The sensor will also have specific optical and housing geometry characteristics tailored for measurement of sinking particle fluxes. The development stages will consist of optical modeling of proposed sensor geometries, modeling of particle collection efficiencies of different housing geometries, laboratory testing of model particles, and dissemination of results to the scientific community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Robotic profiling float observations have driven impressive advances in our understanding of the ocean and its response to climate change. Presently, the international Argo program maintains around 4,000 of these floats globally.  They operate without human intervention during all seasons and weather conditions and provide real-time data to scientists and managers worldwide. It is an understatement to say that this observational capability has revolutionized ocean science. Over the last decade, floats measuring physical properties like salinity and temperature have been augmented with chemical and biological sensors that measure properties such as oxygen, nutrients, acidity, and concentrations of particles like phytoplankton (unicellular organisms that comprise the base of the open-ocean food web). These additional measurements provide key data on the interactions of the ocean?s biology, carbon cycle, and Earth?s climate.  In the ocean, biological and physical processes transfer carbon from the atmosphere and surface ocean into deep water where it is sequestered for long periods of time, impacting the global climate. The rate of this carbon transfer is comparable to humanity?s fossil fuel emissions, but it is not precisely known (estimates vary over a range of greater than 80%). A sensor carried aboard autonomous profiling floats that can help to quantify this carbon transfer will therefore be of great value.

This STTR Phase I project investigated the feasibility and commercial potential of an ?optical sediment trap? (OST) sensor that (1) measures the settling particles that carry the greatest amount of biological carbon into the deep ocean, and (2) is designed to meet the challenge of sampling from globally distributed, robotic profiling floats in the ocean. The OST works by collecting sinking particles on a transparent window while the float drifts for several days at depth between profiles.  The window is illuminated, and the ?shadow? cast by the accumulated particles is used to determine the carbon transfer rate. In this project, we established a strong industry-academia collaboration with an expert in measurements of particle transfer in the ocean (Co-I Margaret Estapa at the University of Maine) with a commercial partner having a proven history of developing and bringing ocean optics sensors to market (PI Wayne Slade at Sequoia Scientific, Inc.).

The new OST sensor design will be specifically sensitive to sinking particles over several orders of magnitude in carbon transfer rates, without biases caused by the size and shape of its outer case, or from the size of the particles or their sinking speeds Specific work tasks allowed us to establish that the OST sensor design will not be significantly biased by the proposed sensor?s size, shape, illumination, or the composition of particle settling on the collector window. We used a model simulating the paths of sinking particles in naturally turbulent seawater to determine the optimal sensor shape and placement of the sensor on the profiling float and minimize its sensitivity to particle sinking speeds. We compiled and analyzed field measurements of ocean carbon transfer by particles to optimize the size of the transparent particle collection window and to determine the best angle for the illuminating light. We also built a laboratory mockup of the sensor and collected measurements of particles like those sinking in the ocean. These measurements showed that the sensor was agnostic to the composition and size of particles. Finally, the sensor will meet stability, longevity and cost constraints imposed by global profiling float sampling programs which require low power consumption, small amounts of data transferred over satellite networks, simple computations, and minimal long-term drift.
